document_data.name: Winterflower Duskmere
document_data.mainbody:
Lady '''Winterflower Duskmere''' was an [[elven]] magician during the [[Time of Dragons]], and a heir to House [[Duskmere]].{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|67-70}}

{{quote|Orchtrien marches company after company off to perish in his wars. He was willing to risk your death for a moment's diversion, with never a thought that such an attitude was callous or unjust. We're lesser creatures in his eyes, to exploit as he sees fit.|Winterflower Duskmere, to [[Rhespen Ash]].{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|24-26}}}}
document_data.Description: Her exquisiite features added up to a look of courage and intelligence. She had curly black hair, gold-flecked blue eyes, and fair skin.
document_data.Personality: Winterflower behaved in extremes, to other people, showing herself as either cold and aloof{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|15-17}} However, this was deliberate on her part, to better draw the attentions of the men around her and thus manipulate them to her ends. Her ultimate end, as she explained, was advancing elven freedom, bringing them away from the control of the wyrms.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|58-62}}
document_data.Abilities:
Lady Winterflower's singing was impressive and touching.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|9-10}}

She was a mage of some power, being able to cast ''[[dimensional anchor]]''.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|47-49}} and she was almost certainly involved in the creation of the ''[[Dracorage mythal]]''.
document_data.Possessions: Lady Winterflower Duskmere possessed a number of spellbooks, which she was not allowed to bring to Dawnfire.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|19-22}} Her room in the palace was initially furnished exclusively with elven finery. The lady's most prized possession was a jewelry box.
document_data.Relationships: She tried to seduce King [[Orchtrien]], and became his mistress for a time, but her true love was for [[Rhespen Ash]].

History.-25,089 DR:
Despite her initial outrage, Winterflower became the King's mistress over winter.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|34}} Per Orchtrien, she warmed up to him and claimed to fall in love with the king over time.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|35-37}}

When Rhespen turned up at her door, she claimed to be afflicted by an intermittent enchantment that made him fall heads over heels for the king, granting her precious few reprieves from the magic. In response, Rhespen erased the encounter from her mind with a spell, and set forth.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|38-40}} He returned after copying the King's spells, and used one spell to erase the enchantment from her mind; she acted as though released, but their door was then kicked in by Maldur and several of Orchtrien's crossbowmen. Winterflower quickly seized the copied spellbooks, Rhespen's staff, and teleported away.

At the hideout of the Duskmere, Winterflower and other mages took efforts to decipher, first, the spells of concealment against magical search, and that was all they'd managed to achieve before Rhespen Ash snuck inside and tried to retrieve the books. He disabled the other mages, but Winterflower stopped him with a ''[[dimensional anchor]]'' spell; while they talked, Orchtrien found the stronghold. Rhespen's plan to flee with the books and present them to his King thwarted, he agreed to join Winterflower's rebellion, and slow Orchtrien down in combat so that at least some of the books could be taken to other elves.

Lady Duskmere Winterflower was the last and only person who managed to escape with one of Orchtrien's books after the king's men razed the hidden stronghold. She was tempted to discard the book, but decided to persevere in order to make the sacrifices worth it. That eventually led to the creation of the [[Dracorage mythal]].
History.Rumors & Speculation: During a discussion between Rhespen Ash, tortured after turning traitor, and King Orchtrien, the gold dragon surmised that she'd convinced him of her mind control to prompt him towards assassination, and that she'd seduced him too, in order to better spy and perhaps commit regicide.{{cite book/Realms of the Elves/Traitors|50-53}}
